revision.text:
[[File:James Monroe Ingalls.jpg|thumb|right|150px|James Monroe Ingalls]] '''James Monroe Ingalls''' (January 25, 1837 – May 1, 1927) was an [[United States|American]] soldier and an authority on [[ballistics]]. His tabulations on ballistics was the authoritative source for over 100 years.
==Early life== Ingalls was born January 25, 1837, in Sutton Township, [[Caledonia County, Vermont]]. He was the youngest of 9 children of James Ingalls (circa 1792-1866) and Mary Cass (circa 1797-1883). His parents are buried in Forest Hill Cemetery, Madison, Dane County, [[Wisconsin]]. He had a sister, Jane Margaret Ingalls (1821–1920), who married Estes Wilson. Jane Ingalls Wilson was one of the first female physicians in Wisconsin.
Ingalls spent his childhood in [[Clinton, Massachusetts]]. He worked as an errand boy at Lancaster Mills and graduated from Clinton High School in 1856.
==Civil War== James Monroe Ingalls moved to [[Madison, Wisconsin]], with his parents in about 1856. He was a professor of mathematics in the Evansville Seminary, Wisconsin, 1860-1863. He enlisted in the regular army on January 2, 1864, during the [[American Civil War|Civil War]], and was assigned to the 16th Infantry. He was promoted corporal and served as commissary and quartermaster-sergeant until May 21, 1865. He was promoted 2d and 1st lieutenant on May 3, 1865, accepting the promotions on May 21, 1865. On April 17, 1869, he was transferred to the 2d Infantry; on January 1, 1871, to the 1st artillery. He was Commandant of Cadets and Professor of Military Science and Tactics and Mathematics at West Virginia University 1877-78. He was a very popular professor. He was promoted captain of artillery on July 1, 1880; major on June 1, 1897, and lieutenant-colonel on October 5, 1900. He served in Tennessee, Alabama, Georgia and other points in the south between 1864 and 1871, and was then sent to the artillery school at Fort Monroe, graduating in the class of 1872. He was then stationed successively at [[Old Stone Barracks|Plattsburgh Barracks]], and Forts Jefferson and Barrancas, and, in July 1880, was assigned to the command of Battery A, Governor's Island, New York Harbor, and thence transferred to San Francisco Harbor, where he served until ordered to Battery G at Fort Munroe 1882. He suggested and organized the department of ballistics at the artillery school, Fort Monroe, and was made the first instructor on December 19, 1882, which position he held until the school suspended operations in spring 1898 because of the [[Spanish–American War]]. He was also senior instructor in practical artillery exercises, class of 1884; in engineering, class of 1888; in electricity and defensive torpedoes, classes of 1884, 1886, 1888 and 1890; and in signaling, 1884-88. Lieutenant Colonel Ingalls retired from the Army in 1901. In 1904, he was made colonel retired. Ingalls died on May 1, 1927 in [[Providence, Rhode Island]], and is buried in Cedar Grove Cemetery, [[New London, Connecticut]].
Author A. J. Bastarache has called Colonel Ingalls the "Father of Ballistics" for his pioneering research that contributed to America's military successes through the 20th century.
==Family life== Ingalls married Elizabeth Niles, daughter of John S. Niles and Elizabeth Lilly, in July 1860, in [[Dane County, Wisconsin]]. She was born in 1841 in Leon, Cattaraugus County, New York, and died on July 28, 1875 of typhoid fever at [[Fort Barrancas]], [[Escambia County, Florida]], and is buried in the national cemetery there. They had two children. Their son, Arthur Niles Ingalls (1861–1875), also died of typhoid fever and is buried with his mother. Their daughter, Hilda Eliza Ingalls (born September 1868 in McPhersonburg, Virginia) married Joel Randall Burrow in 1889. He later became the Secretary of State of the State of Kansas. Hilda died on November 4, 1908, and is buried at Fairview Cemetery, Smith Center, Kansas.
Ingalls married a second time on July 17, 1877, in New London, Connecticut, to Harriet Elizabeth Thurston, daughter of Benjamin Babcock Thurston, who had been Lieutenant Governor of [[Rhode Island]]. They had one child, Fanny Thurston Ingalls, who never married.
==Publications== * ''Exterior Ballistics'' (1883, 1885, 1886) * ''Ballistic Machines'' (1885) * ''Handbook of Problems in Exterior Ballistics'' (1890; 1901) * ''Ballistic Tables'' (1891; 1900) * ''Interior Ballistics'' (1894; third edition, 1912) * ''Ballistics for the Instruction of Artillery Gunners'' (1893)
==References== {{reflist}} * "COLONEL JAMES M. INGALLS, Veteran of Two Wars and Expert on Ballistics Dies at 90." ''New York Times'', May 2, 1927. * Charles Burleigh, ''The Genealogy and History of the Ingalls Family in America'', 1903. * Francis B Heitman, ''Historical Register & Dictionary of the United States Army'', 1789–1903. Published 1903. * ''The History of the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantation: Biographical''. American Historical Society, Inc., 1920. * A. J. Bastarache, [https://web.archive.org/web/20050725234425/http://www.extraordinarytown.com/ "An Extraordinary Town, How one of America's smallest towns shaped the world"]. the author summarizes Ingalls's accomplishments and history as the "Father of Ballistics".
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ingalls, James Monroe}} [[Category:1837 births]] [[Category:1927 deaths]] [[Category:Ballistics experts]] [[Category:American information and reference writers]] [[Category:American instructional writers]] [[Category:Union Army soldiers]] [[Category:United States Army officers]] [[Category:People from Caledonia County, Vermont]] [[Category:Burials in Connecticut]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} [[File:List of the 214 Kangxi Radicals - old style.svg|right|thumb|400px|List of Kangxi radicals in a font imitating the original character shapes of the [[Kangxi Dictionary]].]] The 214 '''Kangxi radicals''' ({{zh|c=康熙部首|p=Kāngxī bùshǒu}}) form a system of [[radical (Chinese character)|radicals]] ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|部首}}}}) of [[Chinese characters]]. The radicals are numbered in [[stroke (CJKV character)|stroke]] count order. They are the de facto standard used as the basis for most modern [[Chinese dictionaries]], such that reference to "[[radical 61]]", for example, without additional context, refers to the 61st radical of the ''Kangxi Dictionary'', [[:wikt:心|心]]; [[pinyin|''xīn'']] "heart". Originally introduced in the 1615 ''[[Zihui]]'', they are named in relation to the ''[[Kangxi Dictionary]]'' of 1716 (''[[Kangxi Emperor|Kāngxī]]'' {{lang|zh|{{linktext|康|熙}}}} being the [[Chinese era name|era name]] for 1662–1723). The system of 214 Kangxi radicals is based on the older system of [[List of Shuowen Jiezi radicals|540 radicals]] used in the Han-era ''[[Shuowen Jiezi]]''. ==Statistics== {{Unreferenced section|date=October 2016}} [[File:Radicals frequency table.png|thumb|300px|Distribution of the number of entries per radical in the ''Kangxi Dictionary'']] The Kangxi dictionary lists a total of 47,035 characters divided among the 214 radicals, for an average of 220 characters per radical, but distribution is unequal, the [[median]] number of characters per radical being 64, with a maximum number of 1,902 characters (for [[radical 140]] {{lang|zh-Hant|[[:wikt:艸|艸]]}}) and a minimum number of five ([[radical 138]] {{lang|zh-Hant|[[:wikt:艮|艮]]}}). The radicals have between one and seventeen strokes, the median number of strokes being 5 while the average number of strokes is slightly below 5.7. The ten radicals with the largest number of characters account for 10,665 characters (or 23% of the dictionary). The same ten radicals account for 7,141 out of 20,992 characters (34%) in the Unicode [[CJK Unified Ideographs]] block as introduced in 1992, as follows: {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !class="unsortable"|Radical !Kangxi Dictionary ! CJK Unified Ideographs |- |[[Radical 140]] {{lang|zh-Hant|[[:wikt:艸|艸]]}} "grass"|| data-sort-value="1902"| 1,902 characters || 981 characters
(U+8278–864C) |- |[[Radical 85]] {{lang|zh-Hant|[[:wikt:水|水]]}} "water"|| data-sort-value="1595"|1,595 characters || data-sort-value="1079"|1,079 characters
(U+6C34–706A) |- |[[Radical 75]] {{lang|zh-Hant|[[:wikt:木|木]]}} "tree"|| data-sort-value="1369"| 1,369 characters || data-sort-value="1016"|1,016 characters
(U+6728–6B1F) |- |[[Radical 64]] {{lang|zh-Hant|[[:wikt:手|手]]}} "hand"|| data-sort-value="1203"| 1,203 characters || 740 characters
(U+624B–652E) |- |[[Radical 30]] {{lang|zh-Hant|[[:wikt:口|口]]}} "mouth"|| data-sort-value="1146"| 1,146 characters || 756 characters
(U+53E3–56D6) |- |[[Radical 61]] {{lang|zh-Hant|[[:wikt:心|心]]}} "heart"|| data-sort-value="1115"| 1,115 characters || 581 characters
(U+5FC3–6207) |- |[[Radical 142]] {{lang|zh-Hant|[[:wikt:虫|虫]]}} "insect"|| data-sort-value="1067"| 1,067 characters || 469 characters
(U+866B–883F) |- |[[Radical 118]] {{lang|zh-Hant|[[:wikt:竹|竹]]}} "bamboo"|| 953 characters || 378 characters
(U+7AF9–7C72) |- |[[Radical 149]] {{lang|zh-Hant|[[:wikt:言|言]]}} "speech"|| 861 characters || 567 characters
(U+8A00–8C36) |- |[[Radical 120]] {{lang|zh-Hant|[[:wikt:糸|糸]]}} "silk"|| 823 characters || 574 characters
(U+7CF8–7F35) |- |} ==Modern dictionaries== Modern Chinese dictionaries continue to use the Kangxi radical-stroke order, both in traditional ''zìdiǎn'' ({{linktext|字典}}, lit. "character/logograph dictionary") for written [[Chinese character]]s and modern ''cídiǎn'' ({{linktext|詞典}} "word/phrase dictionary") for spoken expressions. The 214 Kangxi radicals act as a de facto standard, which may not be duplicated exactly in every Chinese dictionary, but which few dictionary compilers can afford to completely ignore. They also serve as the basis for many computer encoding systems, including [[Unihan]]. The number of radicals may be reduced in modern practical dictionaries, as some of the more obscure Kangxi radicals do not form any characters that remain in frequent use. Thus, the ''Oxford Concise English–Chinese Dictionary'' ({{ISBN|0-19-596457-8}}), for example, has 188 radicals. The ''[[Xinhua Zidian]]'', a pocket-sized character dictionary containing about 13,000 characters, uses 189 radicals. A few dictionaries also introduce new radicals, treating groups of radicals that are used together in many different characters as a kind of radical. For example, ''[[Hanyu Da Cidian]]'', the most inclusive available [[Chinese dictionary]] (published in 1993) has 23,000 head character entries organised by a novel system of 200 radicals. ==Table of radicals== {| class="wikitable sortable collapsible" !No. !class="unsortable"|Radical (variants) !Stroke count ! class="unsortable" |Meaning ![[Pīnyīn]] ![[Sino-Vietnamese vocabulary|Sino-
Vietnamese]]

|{{lang|zh-Hans|齿}} |{{lang|zh-Hant|齔、齕、齖}} |---- |style="text-align:right"|[[Radical 212|212]] |'''{{lang|zh-Hant|龍}}''' |16 |dragon |lóng |long |りゅう / ryū |용룡 / yongryong |14 |{{lang|zh-Hans|龙}} |{{lang|zh-Hant|龏、龑、龔}} |---- |style="text-align:right"|[[Radical 213|213]] |'''{{lang|zh-Hant|龜}}''' |16 |turtle |guī |quy |かめ / kame |거북귀 / geobukgwi |24 |{{lang|zh-Hans|龟}} |{{lang|zh-Hant|䶰、龝、龞}} |---- |style="text-align:right"|[[Radical 214|214]] |'''{{lang|zh-Hant|龠}}''' |17 |flute |yuè |dược |やく / yaku |피리약 / piriyak |19 | |{{lang|zh-Hant|龡、龢、龤}} |} ==Unicode== {{further|Han unification}} The [[Unicode]] standard encoded 20,992 characters in version 1.0.1 (1992) in the [[CJK Unified Ideographs]] block (U+4E00–9FFF). This standard followed the Kangxi order of radicals ([[radical 1]] at U+4E00, [[radical 214]] at U+9FA0) but did not encode all characters found in the Kangxi dictionary. Individual characters were listed based on their Kangxi radical and number of additional strokes, e.g. U+5382 厂, the unaugmented [[radical 27]] meaning "cliff" is listed under "27.0", while [[:wikt:厃|U+5383]] to [[:wikt:历|U+5386]] are listed under "27.2" as they all consist of radical 27 plus two additional strokes. More characters were added in later versions, adding "CJK Unified Ideographs Extensions" [[CJK Unified Ideographs Extension A|A]], [[CJK Unified Ideographs Extension B|B]], [[CJK Unified Ideographs Extension C|C]] and [[CJK Unified Ideographs Extension D|D]] as of Unicode 7.0 (2014) with further additions planned for Unicode 8.0. Within each "Extension", characters are also ordered by Kangxi radical and additional strokes. The Unicode Consortium maintains the "[[Unihan Database]]", with a [https://www.unicode.org/cgi-bin/UnihanRadicalIndex.pl Radical-Stroke-Index]. The Unicode [[Common Locale Data Repository]] provides no official [[Unicode collation|collation]] (sort order) rule for Unicode CJK characters (short of sorting characters by code point);Ken Whistler, Markus Scherer, [https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr10/#Implicit_Weights Unicode Collation Algorithm, Unicode Technical Standard #10, version 7.0.0] (2014). such collation rules as there are language-specific (such as [[JIS X 0208]] for Japanese kanji) and do not include any of the CJK Unified Ideographs Extension characters. ===Kangxi Radicals block=== {{Infobox Unicode block |blockname = Kangxi Radicals |rangestart = 2F00 |rangeend = 2FDF |script1 = [[Chinese characters|Han]] |symbols = CJK [[Radical (Chinese character)|Radical]] |3_0 = 214 |sources = [[CNS 11643]]-1992 |note = {{cite web|url=https://www.unicode.org|title=Unicode character database|work=The Unicode Standard|accessdate=2016-07-09}}{{cite web|url=https://www.unicode.org/versions/enumeratedversions.html|title=Enumerated Versions of The Unicode Standard|work=The Unicode Standard|accessdate=2016-07-09}} }} In Unicode version 3.0 (1999), a separate Kangxi Radicals block was introduced which encodes the 214 radicals in sequence, at U+2F00–2FD5. These are specific code points intended to represent the radical ''qua'' radical, as opposed to the character consisting of the unaugmented radical; thus, U+2F00 represents [[radical 1]] while U+4E00 represents the character ''yī'' meaning "one". In addition, the [[CJK Radicals Supplement]] block (2E80–2EFF) was introduced, encoding alternative (often positional) forms taken by Kangxi radicals as they appear within specific characters. For example, ⺁ "CJK RADICAL CLIFF" (U+2E81) is a variant of ⼚ [[radical 27]] (U+2F1A), itself identical in shape to the character consisting of unaugmented radical 27, 厂 "cliff" (U+5382). {{Unicode chart Kangxi Radicals}} ===History=== The following Unicode-related documents record the purpose and process of defining specific characters in the Kangxi Radicals block: {| class="wikitable" |- ! /* Historical examples */ Moving content to more appropriate section: In May 1976, ''[[National Geographic World]]'' magazine released 1,000 bottles—250 per week—from the cruise ship [[MS_Formosa_Queen|Song of Norway]],
revision.text:
{{short description|A form of communication in which a written message sealed in a container is released into the conveyance medium}} {{Other uses}} [[File:20160728MessageInBottleComposite.png | thumb | 400px | This bottle and its contents (sample postcard and insert shown above) were launched in 1959 as part of the [[U.S. National Geodetic Survey|U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey]], and were found in 2013.]] A '''message in a bottle''' is a form of communication in which a printed, typed, or handwritten message is sealed in a container (typically a bottle) and released into a conveyance medium (typically a [[body of water]]). Messages in bottles have been used to send distress messages; in [[crowdsourcing|crowdsourced]] scientific studies of ocean currents; as memorial tributes; to send deceased loved ones' ashes on a final journey; to convey expedition reports, and to carry letters or reports from those believing themselves to be doomed. Invitations to prospective [[Pen pal|pen pals]] and letters to actual or imagined love interests have also been sent as messages in bottles. The lore surrounding messages in bottles has often been of a romantic or poetic nature. Use of the term "message in a bottle" has expanded to include metaphorical uses or uses beyond its traditional meaning as bottled messages released into oceans. The term has been applied to plaques on [[spacecraft|craft]] launched into [[outer space]], [[List of interstellar radio messages|interstellar radio messages]], stationary [[time capsule]]s, [[balloon mail]], and containers storing medical information for use by emergency medical personnel. With a growing awareness that bottles constitute waste that can harm the environment and marine life, biodegradable drift cards and wooden blocks are alternatives favored by environmentalists. ==History and uses== Bottled messages may date to about 310 B.C., in water current studies reputed{{sfn |Ebbesmeyer |Scigliano |2009 |p=229 }} to have been carried out by Greek philosopher [[Theophrastus]]. The Japanese medieval epic ''[[The Tale of the Heike]]'' records the story of an exiled poet who, in about 1177 A.D., launched wooden planks on which he had inscribed poems describing his plight.{{sfn |Ebbesmeyer |Scigliano |2009 |pp=54-55 }} In the sixteenth century, [[Elizabeth I of England|Queen Elizabeth I]] created an official position of "Uncorker of Ocean Bottles", and—thinking some bottles might contain secrets from British spies or fleets—decreed that anyone else opening the bottles could face the [[Capital punishment|death penalty]].{{cite web |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2012/09/120918-oldest-message-in-a-bottle-science-history-messages/ |title=Oldest Message in Bottle: Behind History's Famous Floating Notes |first=Jeremy |last=Berlin |work=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]] |date=20 September 2012 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160506022656/http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2012/09/120918-oldest-message-in-a-bottle-science-history-messages/ |archivedate= May 6, 2016 | deadurl=no}}{{sfn |Kraske |1977 |pp=53–56 }} In the nineteenth century, literary works such as [[Edgar Allan Poe]]’s 1833 “[[MS. Found in a Bottle]]” and [[Charles Dickens]]' 1860 "[[A Message from the Sea]]" inspired an enduring popular passion for sending bottled messages.{{sfn |Ebbesmeyer |Scigliano |2009 |pp=55 - 56 }} Scientific experiments involving drift objects—more generally called determinate drifters{{sfn |Ebbesmeyer |Scigliano |2009 |p=50 }}—provide information about currents and help researchers develop ocean circulation maps. For example, experiments conducted in the mid-1700s by [[Benjamin Franklin]] and others indicated the existence and approximate location of the [[Gulf Stream]], with scientific confirmation following in the mid-1800s.{{cite web |last1=Penry |first1=Jerry, LS |title=Message in a Bottle |url=http://www.theamericansurveyor.com/PDF/TheAmericanSurveyor_Penry-MessageInABottle_March2007.pdf |publisher=''The American Surveyor'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923001927/http://www.theamericansurveyor.com/PDF/TheAmericanSurveyor_Penry-MessageInABottle_March2007.pdf |archivedate=September 23, 2014 |date=March 2007 |deadurl=no}} Using a network of [[Beachcombing|beachcomber]] informants, rear admiral Alexander Becher is believed to be the first (from 1808-1852) to study travel of so-called "bottle papers" around an [[ocean gyre]] (a large circulating current system).{{sfn |Ebbesmeyer |Scigliano |2009 |pp=55-56 |ps=, attributing to Becher, Alexander (1843, 1852). ''Nautical Magazine and Naval Chronicle.''}} In the late 1800s, [[Albert I, Prince of Monaco]] determined that the Gulf Stream branched into the [[North Atlantic Current|North Atlantic Drift]] and the [[Azores Current]].{{sfn |Moody |2010 |loc=II. Adrift at Sea }} In the 1890s, Scottish scientist T. Wemyss Fulton released floating bottles and wooden slips to chart [[North Sea]] surface currents for the first time.{{cite web|title=Message in a bottle |url=http://www.gov.scot/News/Releases/2012/08/messagebottle30082012 |publisher=Scottish Government |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6kgs7devI?url=http://www.gov.scot/News/Releases/2012/08/messagebottle30082012 |archivedate=September 21, 2016 |location=News Releases |date=August 30, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} Releasing bottles designed to remain a short distance above the sea bed, British marine biologist [[George Parker Bidder III]] first proved in the early twentieth century that deep sea currents flowed from east to west in the [[North Sea]] and that [[bottom feeder]]s prefer to move against the current.{{cite web|last1=Boxall |first1=Simon |title=Why ocean scientists hope someone gets your message in a bottle |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/world/why-ocean-scientists-hope-someone-gets-your-message-in-a-bottle?http://news.nationalpost.com/news/world/why-ocean-scientists-hope-someone-gets-your-message-in-a-bottle |publisher=''The National Post'' (reprinting from ''The Conversation'') |date=April 25, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qOBdibSK?url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/world/why-ocean-scientists-hope-someone-gets-your-message-in-a-bottle |archivedate=May 11, 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} {{multiple image | align=right | direction=horizontal | image1=189804 Drift Cask CROPPED George Melville.jpg | width1= 105 | caption1=Floating wood-and-metal "drift casks" launched from northern Alaska in 1899-1901 reached Siberia, Iceland and Norway, becoming the first human-made objects to transit the [[Northwest Passage]].{{sfn |Ebbesmeyer |Scigliano |2009 |pp=56-57 |ps=, describing drift casks designed by [[George W. Melville]].}} | image2 = 1960sSeabedDrifterWithStem.png | width2=140 | caption2 =This 1960s-era [[seabed]] drifter includes a descending ballast stem to allow a more buoyant disk to remain just above the seabed to be carried by bottom currents. An imprinted message offers a small reward for reporting the time and place the drifter was found. }} The [[U.S. National Geodetic Survey|U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey (C&GS)]] used drift bottles from 1846 to 1966.{{cite web |last1=Dawicki |first1=Shelley |title=Drift Bottle Found on Martha’s Vineyard Has Quite a Story to Tell |url=http://www.nefsc.noaa.gov/news/features/mv_bottle/ |publisher=NOAA's Northeast Fisheries Science Center (NEFSC) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150210235757/http://www.nefsc.noaa.gov/news/features/mv_bottle |archivedate=February 10, 2015 |date=March 14, 2014 |deadurl=no }} More recently, technologies involving satellite tags, fixed current profilers and satellite communication have permitted more efficient analysis of ocean currents: at any given time, thousands of modern "[[Drifter (floating device)|drifters]]" transmit current position, temperature, velocity, etc., to satellites, thus avoiding conventional drift bottles' dependence on serendipitous finds and cooperation by conscientious citizens.{{cite web |title=NWFSC's Own Message in a Bottle: Ocean Drifters and Tiny Tags Have Been Telling Stories for Decades |url=https://www.nwfsc.noaa.gov/news/features/bottle/bottle.cfm |publisher=NOAA's NWFSC |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160724220756/https://www.nwfsc.noaa.gov/news/features/bottle/bottle.cfm |archivedate=July 24, 2016 |date=2013 |deadurl=no }} Drift bottle studies have provided a simple way to learn about non-tidal movement of waters containing eggs and larvae of commercially important fishes, for sharing among fisheries scientists and oceanographers.{{cite web |last1=Dawicki |first1=Shelley |title=Message in a Bottle: The Story Behind the Story -- Drift Bottles Helped Determine Distribution of Fish Eggs and Larvae |url=http://www.nefsc.noaa.gov/news/features/drift_bottles/ |publisher=NOAA's Northeast Fisheries Science Center (NEFSC) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160725003703/http://www.nefsc.noaa.gov/news/features/drift_bottles/ |archivedate=July 25, 2016 |date=March 14, 2014 |deadurl=no }} Such experiments simulate the travel of pollutants such as oil spills, study formation of [[ocean gyre]] "[[Great Pacific garbage patch|garbage patches]]", and suggest travel paths of [[invasive species]]. Persistent currents are detected to allow ships to ride favorable currents and avoid opposing currents. Projected travel paths of navigation hazards, such as [[naval mine]]s, advise safer shipping routes.{{cite web |last1=Lederer |first1=Muriel |title=Letters from the Sea |url=http://ufdcimages.uflib.ufl.edu/UF/00/09/73/66/00002/UF00097366_00002.pdf |publisher=''The Panama Canal Review'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160904202128/http://ufdcimages.uflib.ufl.edu/UF/00/09/73/66/00002/UF00097366_00002.pdf |archivedate=September 4, 2016 |location=University of Florida Digital Collections |date=Fall 1971 |deadurl=no}} Even in inland waterways, [[Drifter (floating device)|drifters]] wirelessly deliver real-time data on water quality, GPS location, and water velocity, for early warning against flash floods, measuring pollution run-off, and monitoring algal blooms.{{cite news |last1=Kennedy |first1=Matt |title=QUT deploys high-tech "message in a bottle" to fight floods and pollution in river systems |url=https://newatlas.com/qut-flood-pollution-detector/55572/ |work=New Atlas |date=July 23, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180724120414/https://newatlas.com/qut-flood-pollution-detector/55572/ |archivedate=July 24, 2018 |deadurl=no }} Outside science, many launch bottled messages to find [[pen pal]]s,{{sfn |Ebbesmeyer |Scigliano |2009 |pp=57-58 }} "bottle preachers"{{sfn |Kraske |1977 |pp=50–52 }} have sent "sermon bottles",{{sfn |Ebbesmeyer |Scigliano |2009 |pp=62-67 }} [[propaganda]]-bearing bottles have been directed at foreign shores,{{sfn |Ebbesmeyer |Scigliano |2009 |pp=57-58 }}{{cite web |last1=Fifield |first1=Ann |title=With food and facts carried in bottles, activists try to penetrate isolated North Korea |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/with-food-and-facts-carried-in-bottles-activists-try-to-penetrate-isolated-north-korea/2018/04/23/abbe2582-438e-11e8-baaf-8b3c5a3da888_story.html |publisher=''The Washington Post'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180424124805/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/with-food-and-facts-carried-in-bottles-activists-try-to-penetrate-isolated-north-korea/2018/04/23/abbe2582-438e-11e8-baaf-8b3c5a3da888_story.html |archivedate=April 24, 2018 |date=April 24, 2018 |deadurl=no}} and survivors have sent deceased loved ones' ashes on a final journey.{{cite web |title=Woman Finds Ashes and Message in a Bottle, 4 Years After It Was Sent Out to Sea |url=http://www.insideedition.com/woman-finds-ashes-and-message-bottle-4-years-after-it-was-sent-out-sea-37911 |publisher=''Inside Edition'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108213846/http://www.insideedition.com/woman-finds-ashes-and-message-bottle-4-years-after-it-was-sent-out-sea-37911 |archivedate=November 8, 2017 |date=November 8, 2017 |deadurl=no }} It was estimated in 2009 that since the mid-1900s, six million bottled messages had been released, including 500,000 from oceanographers.{{sfn |Ebbesmeyer |Scigliano |2009 |p=67 }} ==Bottle design, and recovery rates== Some bottles are ballasted with dry sand so that they float vertically at or near the ocean surface, and are less influenced by winds and breaking waves than other bottles that are purposely not ballasted. Wooden blocks float higher in the water and thus are ''more'' influenced by wind—a design specially suited for simulating travel paths of plastic waste that is less dense than glass containers.{{cite web |last1=Melanie |first1=Hall |title=Tackling plastic waste in oceans with 'wooden message in a bottle' |url=http://www.dw.com/en/tackling-plastic-waste-in-oceans-with-wooden-message-in-a-bottle/a-36031567 |publisher=''Deutsche Welle'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018043919/http://www.dw.com/en/tackling-plastic-waste-in-oceans-with-wooden-message-in-a-bottle/a-36031567 |archivedate=October 18, 2016 |date=October 13, 2016 |deadurl=no }} A research program from the University of Oldenburg (Germany) involves 100,000 wooden blocks of various thicknesses. An early-20th-century "bottom" (or [[seabed]]) drift bottle design by [[George Parker Bidder III]] involved weighting a bottle with a long copper wire that causes it to sink until the wire trails upon the sea bottom, at which time the bottle tends to remain a few inches above the bottom to be moved by the bottom current. A mushroom-shaped seabed drifter design has also been used. Seabed drifters are designed to be scooped up by a [[Fishing trawler|trawler]] or wash up on shore. Water pressure pressing on the cork or other closure was thought to keep a bottle better sealed; some designs included a wooden stick to stop the cork from imploding. Vessels of less scientific designs have survived for extended periods, including a [[baby food]] bottle{{cite web|last1=Peterson |first1=Eric |title='Message in a bottle' found in bay apparently dates to Vietnam War era |url=http://fox11online.com/news/local/lakeshore/message-found-in-bottle-dates-back-to-vietnam-war |publisher=Fox 11 News (Green Bay, WI, U.S.) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160528154639/http://fox11online.com/news/local/lakeshore/message-found-in-bottle-dates-back-to-vietnam-war |archivedate=May 28, 2016 |date=May 27, 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }} • {{cite web|last1=Peterson |first1=Eric |title=Message in bottle mystery may be getting clearer |url=http://fox11online.com/news/local/lakeshore/message-in-bottle-mystery-may-be-getting-clearer |publisher=Fox 11 News (Green Bay, WI, U.S.) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602105100/http://fox11online.com/news/local/lakeshore/message-in-bottle-mystery-may-be-getting-clearer |archivedate=June 2, 2016 |date=June 1, 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }} a [[ginger beer]] bottle, and a [[7-Up]] bottle. A low percentage of bottles—thought by some to be less than 3 percent—are actually recovered, so they are released in large numbers, sometimes in the thousands. Reported recovery rates for large-scale scientific studies vary based on the ocean of release, and range from 11 percent ([[Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution|Woods Hole]], 156,276 bottles from 1948–1962, Atlantic), to 10 percent (Woods Hole, 165,566 bottles from 1960–1970, Atlantic), to 3.4 percent ([[Scripps Institution of Oceanography|Scripps Institution]], 148,384 bottles from 1954–1971, Pacific).{{sfn |Kraske |1977 |pp=88–89 }} Oceanographic drift card recovery rates have ranged from 50 percent if released in densely populated areas ([[North Sea]], [[Puget Sound]]) to 1 percent in uninhabited areas ([[Antarctica]]).{{sfn |Ebbesmeyer |Scigliano |2009 |p=67 }} Recovery rates decrease as bottles are released further from shore, with oceanographer [[Curtis Ebbesmeyer]] developing a rule of thumb that bottles released more than 100 miles from shore have recovery rates below 10 percent, and "only a few percent" of those released more than 1000 miles from shore are recovered.{{cite web|last1=Heidorn |first1=Keith C. |title=Of Shoes And Ships And Rubber Ducks And A Message In A Bottle |url=http://www.islandnet.com/~see/weather/elements/shoes.htm |website=IslandNet.com |location="The Weather Doctor" section |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513190816/http://www.islandnet.com/~see/weather/elements/shoes.htm |archivedate=May 13, 2016 |date=March 17, 1999 |deadurl=no |df= }} Article updated October 2010. A Scripps scientist said that marine organisms grow on the bottles, causing them to sink within eight to ten months unless washed ashore earlier.{{sfn |Kraske |1977 |p=89 }} An unknown number are found but not reported.{{sfn |Kraske |1977 |p=89 }} ==Time and distance== Some drift bottles were not found for more than a century after being launched. {{Quote box |title = |quote = ''Drift bottles and seabed drifters
provide only a birth notice and an obituary
with no biography.'' |source = 1973, Dean F. Bumpus, Senior Scientist
Woods Hole Oceanographic Inst.● {{cite journal |last1=Bumpus |first1=Dean F. |title=A description of the circulation on the continental shelf of the east coast of the United States |journal=Progress in Oceanography |date=1973 |volume=6 |page=150 |doi=10.1016/0079-6611(73)90006-2 |publisher=Elsevier Ltd.|bibcode=1973PrOce...6..111B }} ● Quotation is freely accessible online from full-text secondary source: {{cite journal|last1=Fischer|first1=Hugo B.|title=Mixing processes on the Atlantic continental shelf, Cape Cod to Cape Hatteras|journal=Limnol. Oceanogr.|date=January 1980|volume=25|issue=1|page=115|doi=10.4319/lo.1980.25.1.0114|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/store/10.4319/lo.1980.25.1.0114/asset/lno19802510114.pdf?v=1&t=ist2ig0s&s=dae6d5e91e0eb3999643bad2f30c33c16ad6499c|publisher=American Society of Limnology and Oceanography, Inc. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160907154618/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/store/10.4319/lo.1980.25.1.0114/asset/lno19802510114.pdf?v=1&t=ist2ig0s&s=dae6d5e91e0eb3999643bad2f30c33c16ad6499c |archivedate= September 7, 2016 |deadurl=no |bibcode=1980LimOc..25..114F}} |align = right |width = 25% |border = 1px |fontsize = 100% |bgcolor = #f0f0ff |title_bg = #f0f0ff |title_fnt = #202060 |qalign = left |salign = right }} Floating objects may ride [[Ocean gyre|gyres]] (large circulating current systems) that are present in each ocean, and may be transferred from one ocean's gyre to another's. Further, objects may be sidetracked by wind, storms, countercurrents, and ocean current variation.{{cite web|last1=Krajick |first1=Kevin |title=Message in a Bottle |url=http://courses.washington.edu/ocean200/Readings/Ebbesmeyer.pdf |publisher=University of Washington |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918214856/http://courses.washington.edu/ocean200/Readings/Ebbesmeyer.pdf |archivedate=September 18, 2016 |date=2001 |deadurl=no}} From ''Smithsonian,'' July 2001, pp. 36-42. Accordingly, drift bottles have traveled large distances, with drifts of 4,000 to 6,000 miles and more—sometimes traveling 100 miles per day—not uncommon. Bottles have traveled from the Beaufort Sea above northern Alaska and northwestern Canada to northern Europe; from Antarctica to Tasmania; from Mexico to the Philippines; from Canada's Labrador Sea and Baffin Bay to Irish, French, Scottish, and Norwegian beaches; from the Galapagos Islands to Australia;{{cite web |last1=White |first1=Jorgia |title=Queensland police officer finds message in a bottle |url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/queensland-police-officer-finds-message-in-a-bottle-20160227-gn5g63.html |publisher=''Brisbane Times'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160322183330/http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/queensland-police-officer-finds-message-in-a-bottle-20160227-gn5g63.html |archivedate=March 22, 2016 |date=February 27, 2016 |deadurl=no }} and from New Zealand to Spain (practically [[antipodes]]).{{cite web |last1=Carter |first1=Charlotte |title=Message in the bottle from Whangarei to Spain may be a record breaker |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12012437 |publisher=''New Zealand Herald'' |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6y70bAde5?url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12012437 |archivedate=March 22, 2018 |date=March 14, 2018 |deadurl=no }} Based on empirical data collected since 1901, a computer program called OSCURS (Ocean Surface Current Simulator) digitally simulates motion and timing of floating objects in and between ocean gyres.{{cite web|last1=Ingraham, Jr. |first1=W. James |title=Getting to Know OSCURS, REFM's Ocean Surface Current Simulator |url=http://www.afsc.noaa.gov/REFM/docs/oscurs/get_to_know.htm |publisher=Alaska Fisheries Science Center (NOAA) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161128233913/http://www.afsc.noaa.gov/REFM/docs/oscurs/get_to_know.htm |archivedate=November 28, 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }} Originally published in the Alaska Fisheries Science Center ''Quarterly Report,'' April–May-June, 1997. Program limited North Pacific from 10° N latitude to the Bering Strait. Despite being launched substantial ''time periods'' before being found, some bottles have been found physically close to their original launch points, such as a message launched by two girls in 1915 and found in 2012 near [[Harsens Island]], Michigan, U.S., and a ten-year-old girl's message launched into the Indian River Bay in Delaware, U.S. in 1971 and found in adjacent Delaware Seashore State Park in 2016. ==Historical examples== ''Historical examples are listed in chronological order, based on year of recovery (when applicable):'' * It is reputed{{sfn |Ebbesmeyer |Scigliano |2009 |p=229 }} that about 310 BC, Aristotle's protegé, Greek philosopher [[Theophrastus]] used bottled messages to determine if the [[Mediterranean Sea]] was formed by the [[Inflow (hydrology)|inflow]]ing [[Atlantic Ocean]]. [[File:1786-Benjamin-Franklin-Gulf-Stream-cropped.jpg | thumb | This late-1700s ocean circulation map was based on the work of [[Benjamin Franklin]] and James Poupard after conducting drift bottle experiments, apparently still unaware of the [[Gulf Stream]]'s origin in the [[Gulf of Mexico]].]] * When [[Christopher Columbus]] encountered a severe storm while returning from America, he is said to have written on parchment what he had found in the New World and requested it be forwarded to King [[Ferdinand II of Aragon|Ferdinand]] and Queen [[Isabella I of Castile|Isabella]], enclosed the parchment in a waxed cloth and placed it into a large wooden barrel to be cast into the sea. The communication was never found.{{cite book |last1=Bergreen |first1=Laurence |title=Columbus: The Four Voyages, 1492-1504 |date=September 25, 2012 |publisher=Penguin Books |isbn=978-0143122104 |edition=Reprint |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Dyhtkk4VQcC&pg=PT117&lpg=PT117&dq=columbus+%22message+in+a+bottle%22+isabella+-ohio&source=bl&ots=u5CFqCnmgL&sig=KTlGohBINoqDGmXlG0krfBZlh84&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiTgoqH3ZzOAhWINiYKHXUsBSEQ6AEISTAI#v=onepage&q=columbus%20%22message%20in%20a%20bottle%22%20isabella%20-ohio&f=false }} "Part One: Discovery" (exact page does not show in Google Books preview). * In 1784 [[Castaway#Chunosuke Matsuyama|Chunosuke Matsuyama]] sent a message detailing his and 43 shipmates' shipwrecking in a bottle that washed ashore and was found in 1935 by a Japanese seaweed collector in the village of Hiraturemura, Matsuyama's birthplace.{{sfn |Kraske |1977 |pp=40–41 }} * In 1847, from the brig ''Eagle'' laden with corn for the starving Irish in Waterford, Ireland, master Gregg dropped a bottled message with his location (42.40N, 54.10W) on March 27, requesting the find be sent to the ''Nautical Magazine'' (London) for publication to provide information on Atlantic currents. The bottle was retrieved on July 20 by Capt. Robert Oke on a revenue cutter off the coast of Newfoundland (55.30W, 46.36N).{{cite news |author= |date=14 Aug 1847 |title=Memoranda |url=http://collections.mun.ca/cdm/compoundobject/collection/morncourier/id/930/rec/1 |newspaper= Morning Courier |location=St. John’s, NL |page=3 |access-date= 7 Mar 2017}} Accessed via the Memorial University of Newfoundland Digital Archives Initiative. * In 1875, ship's steward Van Hoydek and cabin boy Henry Trusillo of the British sailing ship ''Lennie'' released 24 bottled messages into the [[Bay of Biscay]], telling of the murder by mutineers of their captain and officers. French authorities soon received the message, rescued Hoydek and Trusillo, and brought the mutineers to justice.{{cite web |title=Mutiny and Murder on the High Seas |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/97420881 |publisher=''The Western Star'' |location=National Library of Australia (NLA) Trove digitized newspapers |date=May 13, 1876 }}{{sfn |Kraske |1977 |pp=57–59 }} * In 1876, on the remote Scottish island of [[St Kilda, Scotland#Way of life|St Kilda]], freelance journalist John Sands and marooned Austrian sailors deployed two messages requesting the Austrian Consul rescue them with provisions. The messages, each enclosed in a cocoa tin attached to a sheep’s bladder for flotation in an arrangement later called a "St. Kilda mail boat",{{cite web |title=St Kilda Mail Boat reaches Norway |url=http://www.stornowaygazette.co.uk/what-s-on/leisure-time/st-kilda-mail-boat-reaches-norway-1-3930408 |publisher=''Stornoway Gazette'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151029103524/http://www.stornowaygazette.co.uk/what-s-on/leisure-time/st-kilda-mail-boat-reaches-norway-1-3930408 |archivedate=October 29, 2015 |date=October 28, 2015 |deadurl=no }} were discovered in [[Orkney]] within nine days and in [[Ross, Scotland|Ross-Shire]] after 22 days. Since that time, sending "St. Kilda mail" has become a recreational ritual for island visitors, the containers often riding the [[Gulf Stream]] to the British mainland, [[Shetland]], [[Orkney]] and [[Scandinavia]].{{cite web |last1=Murray |first1=Keegan |title=Sandwick bairns find ‘St Kilda Mailboat’ |url=http://www.shetlandtimes.co.uk/2016/03/27/sandwick-bairns-find-st-kilda-mailboat |publisher=''The Shetland Times'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416095930/http://www.shetlandtimes.co.uk/2016/03/27/sandwick-bairns-find-st-kilda-mailboat |archivedate=April 16, 2016 |date=March 27, 2016 |deadurl=no }} * Message-bearing bottles from [[RMS Titanic|''Titanic'']] (1912) and [[RMS Lusitania|''Lusitania'']] (1915) have been widely recounted as fact, but even before these bottles were found ''The Irish News'' stated in April 1912 that "very many" such stories turn out to be "cruel hoaxes".{{cite news |last1=Moloney |first1=Senan |title=Faces of the Titanic: Jeremiah Burke sent a message in a bottle before his death |url=http://www.irishcentral.com/news/faces-of-the-titanic-jeremiah-burke-lost-his-life-at-19-put-a-message-in-a-bottle-before-he-died-146337625-237439851.html |work=IrishCentral.com |date=April 2, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415182346/http://www.irishcentral.com/news/faces-of-the-titanic-jeremiah-burke-lost-his-life-at-19-put-a-message-in-a-bottle-before-he-died-146337625-237439851.html |archivedate=April 15, 2016 |deadurl=no}} Moloney quotes passages from other newspapers, including ''The Irish News.'' * In February 1916, when German [[LZ 54 (L 19)|Zeppelin L 19]] experienced unfavorable weather, battle damage and multiple engine failure after attacking the British [[The Midlands|Midlands]], its commander's last message to superiors and the crew's final letters to relatives were released into the North Sea to be found on a Swedish coast six months later.{{cite web|url=http://www.zeppelin-museum.dk/D/german/historie/l-19/l-19.html|title=Das Tragödie von L19 (The tragedy of L19) |publisher=Zeppelin-Museums Tondern (Denmark) |language=German |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020702171704/http://www.zeppelin-museum.dk/D/german/historie/l-19/l-19.html |archivedate=July 2, 2002 |deadurl=no }}{{cite web |title=Last Messages from "L 19" |url=http://flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1916/1916%20-%200709.html |publisher=[[Flightglobal]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141104104317/http://flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1916/1916%20-%200709.html |archivedate=November 4, 2014 |page=707 |date=August 17, 1916 |deadurl=no}} The written descriptions of how a British fishing trawler had refused to rescue the downed Zeppelin's crew—the trawler captain claiming he feared the German airmen would overpower his own unarmed crew—contributed to an enduring international controversy.''See'' {{cite web |title=Inside Out investigates why air raid on Midlands led to British fisherman being accused of war crimes |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2005/02_february/15/io_airraids.shtml |publisher=BBC |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050306230522/http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2005/02_february/15/io_airraids.shtml |archivedate=March 6, 2005 |date=February 15, 2005 |deadurl=no }} *On December 23, 1927, [[Frances Wilson Grayson]], niece of U.S. President [[Woodrow Wilson]], was to attempt to be the first woman to make a transatlantic flight (non-solo). However, her Sikorsky amphibian plane disappeared en route from New York's [[Long Island]] to [[Harbour Grace]], Newfoundland, and was never found. A bottled message was found in [[Salem Harbor]], Massachusetts, in January 1929, the unauthenticated message reading, "1928, we are freezing. Gas leaked out. We are drifting off Grand Banks. Grayson.”{{cite web|last1=Chase |first1=Sean |title=Vanished at sea -the doomed obsession of Frances Wilson Grayson |url=http://www.thedailyobserver.ca/2010/12/09/vanished-at-sea-the-doomed-obsession-of-frances-wilson-grayson |publisher=''The Daily Observer'' |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6pwW6QZFB?url=http://www.thedailyobserver.ca/2010/12/09/vanished-at-sea-the-doomed-obsession-of-frances-wilson-grayson |archivedate=April 23, 2017 |date=December 9, 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }} [[File:'The Children of Captain Grant' by Édouard Riou 004.jpg | thumb | align=right | This romanticized [[Édouard Riou]] drawing of a message in a bottle was included in [[Jules Verne]]'s 1860s book ''[[In Search of the Castaways]].{{cite book |last1=Verne |first1=Jules |title=In Search of the Castaways |date=1874 |publisher=J.B. Lippincott & Co., Philadelphia (original publisher) |edition=Project Gutenberg eBook released August 16, 2014 |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/46597/46597-h/46597-h.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160327004414/http://www.gutenberg.org/files/46597/46597-h/46597-h.htm |archivedate=March 27, 2016 |chapter=Chapter 1. The Shark |deadurl=no }}]] * In 1929, a bottle that came to be known as the Flying Dutchman was released by a German marine science expedition with instructions for any finders to report the find but return the bottle to the sea.{{sfn |Moody |2010 |loc=II. Adrift at Sea }} Found at several locations in succession, the Flying Dutchman traveled 16,000 miles from its release point in the southern [[Indian Ocean]], to [[Cape Horn]] in South America, and back through the Indian Ocean to its last reported find in 1935 on the west coast of Australia.{{sfn |Moody |2010 |loc=II. Adrift at Sea }} * On Christmas Day 1945, 21-year-old medical corpsman [[Frank Hayostek]] threw a message-laden aspirin bottle from his [[Liberty ship]] as it approached New York, the bottle being found eight months later near [[Dingle]], [[County Kerry]], by Irish milkmaid Breda O'Sullivan. Her mailed reply began a correspondence that inspired Hayostek to save money for airfare to visit O'Sullivan in 1952. Intense media attention for the "impossibly romantic story", including [[Time (magazine)|''Time'' magazine]] stories, overshadowed their two-week visit, the two parting but corresponding until they married other people in 1958 and 1959. Media attention endured through the sixtieth anniversary of their meeting,''See'' {{cite web |title=Documentary on One: Message in a Bottle |url=http://www.rte.ie/radio1/doconone/2012/1228/647286-documentary-podcast-message-in-a-bottle-frank-hayostek-breda-osullivan/ |publisher=RTÉ Radio One |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150525223242/http://www.rte.ie/radio1/doconone/2012/1228/647286-documentary-podcast-message-in-a-bottle-frank-hayostek-breda-osullivan/ |archivedate=May 25, 2015 |date=August 4, 2012 |deadurl=no }} Site includes downloadable mp3 podcast. 2–3 years after their deaths.{{cite web|last1=Quinlan |first1=Ailin |title=The GI and the Irish colleen |url=http://www.independent.ie/lifestyle/the-gi-and-the-irish-colleen-26883730.html |publisher=''Irish Independent'' |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6jRmFJ4kY?url=http://www.independent.ie/lifestyle/the-gi-and-the-irish-colleen-26883730.html |archivedate=August 1, 2016 |date=August 5, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} * In 1955, a bottle from a 1903 German [[Antarctica|Antarctic]] expedition was found in [[New Zealand]], about 3400 miles from its launch point between the [[Kerguelen Islands]] and [[Tasmania]]; however, [[Hydrography|hydrographers]] surmise it had drifted around the world many times.{{cite news |title=Bottles washed up on beaches with various corked messages |url=https://www.myheritage.com/research/collection-10450/australian-newspapers?itemId=9216673&action=showRecord |work=The Canberra Times |date=August 7, 1991 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160906142008/https://www.myheritage.com/research/collection-10450/australian-newspapers?itemId=9216673&action=showRecord |archivedate=September 6, 2016 |location=National Library of Australia (NLA) via MyHeritage.com |page=23 |deadurl=no }} * In 1956, Swedish sailor Ake Viking sent a bottled message “To Someone Beautiful and Far Away” that reached a 17-year-old Sicilian girl named Paolina, sparking a correspondence that culminated in their marriage in 1958.{{cite web |last1=Breyer |first1=Melissa |title=Message in a bottle: 8 striking stories of letters sent to sea |url=http://www.mnn.com/lifestyle/arts-culture/stories/message-in-a-bottle-8-striking-stories-of-letters-sent-to-sea |publisher=Mother Nature Network |date=August 11, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130816004008/http://www.mnn.com/lifestyle/arts-culture/stories/message-in-a-bottle-8-striking-stories-of-letters-sent-to-sea |archivedate=August 16, 2013 |deadurl=no }} • Confirmed accurate, with a 1959 quotation from ''[[The American Weekly]],'' at [http://hoaxes.org/weblog/comments/man_meets_wife_via_message_in_a_bottle "Man Meets Wife Via Message-in-a-Bottle"], hoaxes.org, August 18, 2007 ([https://web.archive.org/web/20151209162643*/http://hoaxes.org/weblog/comments/man_meets_wife_via_message_in_a_bottle archive]). The affair attracted so much attention that 4,000 people celebrated their wedding.{{cite web |last1=Randazzo |first1=Antonio |title=Sposi in bottiglia Siracusa (Spouse in a Bottle -- Syracuse) |url=http://www.antoniorandazzo.it/ricordando/sposi-in-bottiglia-siracusa.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160815215240/http://www.antoniorandazzo.it/ricordando/sposi-in-bottiglia-siracusa.html |archivedate=August 15, 2016 |date=2008 |deadurl=no }} Images also [https://web.archive.org/web/20160815215641/http://anteassrcenacolopoetico.blogspot.com/2008/03/matrimonio-in-bottiglia.html here]. * In 1959 [[Guinness Brewery]] launched 150,000 bottles into the Atlantic Ocean and Caribbean Sea in a promotional campaign. It was reported that [[Inuit]] hunters on [[Coats Island]], in Canada's [[Hudson Bay]], found 80 of the bottles. * In May 1976, ''[[National Geographic World]]'' magazine released 1,000 bottles—250 per week—from the cruise ship [[MS_Formosa_Queen|Song of Norway]], with instructions in five languages to fill out and return cards, in order to help map ocean currents.{{cite news |title=Fishing for Bottles |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/wilson-daily-times-jul-26-1976-p-3/ |work=Wilson Daily Times ''(Associated Press)''|date=July 26, 1976 |page=3 }} * A message that an American couple released from a cruise ship approaching [[Hawaii]] in 1979 was found off [[Songkhla Province|Songkhla Beach, Thailand]] by a former South Vietnamese soldier and his family as they fled that country's communist regime by boat. A correspondence relationship began in 1983, and the couple worked with [[Immigration and Naturalization Service|U.S. Immigration]] to help the Vietnamese family obtain [[Refugee#Refugee status|refugee status]] in 1985 and move to the U.S.{{cite web |last1=Becklund |first1=Laurie |title=Bobbing Message at Sea Alters Viet Refugees' Lives : Note in Bottle--a Ticket to Freedom |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-04-26/news/mn-20828_1_refugee-camp |publisher=''Los Angeles Times'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328055639/http://articles.latimes.com/1985-04-26/news/mn-20828_1_refugee-camp |archivedate=March 28, 2012 |date=April 26, 1985 |deadurl=no}} * In 1991 a bottled message found on [[Vancouver Island]], Canada, urged the release of Chinese dissident [[Wei Jingsheng]]. Believed to have been released in 1980 near [[Quemoy]] Island, China, it is thought to be among [[Taiwan]] propaganda bottles launched toward mainland [[China]]. * In what was described as "perhaps the most famous message in a bottle love story", in March 1999 a green ginger beer bottle was dredged up by a fisherman off the [[Essex]] coast, the bottle containing an 84 year old letter tossed into the [[English channel]] on September 9, 1914 by British soldier Private Thomas Hughes days before he was killed in fighting in France. Hughes' letter, written for delivery to his wife who had died in 1979, was delivered instead to his then 86-year-old daughter in [[New Zealand]] by the fisherman himself, who with his own wife was flown to New Zealand at the expense of [[New Zealand Post]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/346879.stm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091030075740/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/346879.stm |archivedate=October 30, 2009 |date=May 18, 1999 |publisher=BBC News |title=Sweet message in a bottle |deadurl=no }} • Some references ([https://web.archive.org/web/20160320165737/http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/879168/HUGHES%2C%20THOMAS example: Commonwealth War Graves Commission]) state that Hughes died twelve days later, not two days later as most popularly reported. [[File:1906MarineBiolAssnPostcard.png | thumb | This postcard, inserted into a bottle launched by the Marine Biological Association of the U.K. ''circa'' 1906, was found in 2015.]] * A teardrop-shaped bottle was found in March 2002 on a beach in Kent, U.K., containing an unsigned letter from a French woman expressing her enduring grief over the death of her son at age 13. British author [[Karen Liebreich]] spent years of research, unsuccessfully trying to find the mother and eventually publishing a book ''The Letter in the Bottle'' (2006). The book was published in French in 2009, sparking huge media coverage that alerted the mother for the first time that her letter had actually been discovered. Saying she initially felt violated by publication of her personal suffering, the mother told Liebreich on condition of continued anonymity, the details of her son's 1981 death in a bicycle accident, her decades of suffering afterwards, and the story surrounding release of her letter from an [[English Channel]] ferry.{{cite web |last1=Daoust |first1=Phil |title=I found a message in a bottle |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/aug/14/karen-liebreich-letter-in-a-bottle |publisher=''The Guardian''|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160909181857/https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/aug/14/karen-liebreich-letter-in-a-bottle |archivedate=September 9, 2016 |date=August 13, 2010 |deadurl=no }}{{cite web |last1=Liebreich |first1=Karen |title=The mystery of the message in the bottle |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/7836150/The-mystery-of-the-message-in-the-bottle.html |publisher=''The Daily Telegraph'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100630085244/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/7836150/The-mystery-of-the-message-in-the-bottle.html |archivedate=June 30, 2010 |date=June 27, 2010 |deadurl=no }} * In May 2005, three days after eighty-eight migrants were abandoned by [[People smuggling|human smugglers]] on a disabled boat, the migrants tied an SOS-bearing bottle to a long line of a passing fishing vessel, whose captain alerted authorities to rescue the migrants.{{cite web|last1=Jimenez |first1=Marianela |title=Message in bottle saves stranded migrants |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/jun/01/1 |publisher=''The Guardian''; Associated Press |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130829055738/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/jun/01/1 |archivedate=August 29, 2013 |date=May 31, 2005 |deadurl=no }} * On December 10, 2006, a bottom drift bottle, released on April 25, 1914 northeast of the [[Shetland]] Islands by the Marine Laboratory, Aberdeen, U.K., was recovered by a Shetland fisherman, after the bottle had spent over 92 years at sea.{{cite web |title=Oldest message in a bottle |url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/records-1/oldest-message-in-a-bottle/ |publisher=Guinness World Records |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120202015451/http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/records-1/oldest-message-in-a-bottle/ |archivedate=February 2, 2012 |date=February 2, 2012 |deadurl=yes }} Guinness web page was subsequently superseded; refer instead to archive link. * In October 2011 in waters off [[Somalia]], the crew of the [[Piracy|pirated]] cargo ship ''Montecristo'' used a bottle with a flashing beacon to alert [[NATO]] ships that they had retreated to an armored room, permitting a military rescue operation to proceed with knowledge that the crew was not being held hostage.{{cite web |last1=Rawnsley |first1=Adam |title=Message in a Bottle: Old-School S.O.S. Helps Rescue Hijacked Ship |url=https://www.wired.com/2011/10/old-school-sos/ |publisher=''Wired'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817060212/https://www.wired.com/2011/10/old-school-sos/ |archivedate=August 17, 2016 |date=October 14, 2011 |deadurl=no }} * In April 2012 a fisherman recovered a bottom drift bottle that had been released 98 years earlier, on June 10, 1914,{{cite web |last1=Madrigal |first1=Alexis C. |title=Found: World's Oldest Message in a Bottle, Part of 1914 Citizen-Science Experiment |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2012/09/found-worlds-oldest-message-in-a-bottle-part-of-1914-citizen-science-experiment/261981/ |publisher=''The Atlantic'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304101117/http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2012/09/found-worlds-oldest-message-in-a-bottle-part-of-1914-citizen-science-experiment/261981/ |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |date=September 5, 2012 |deadurl=no }} one of 1,890 released by the Glasgow School of Navigation to test undercurrents in the seas around Scotland.{{cite web |last1=Pfeiffer |first1=Eric |title=98-year-old message in bottle sets world record |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/blogs/sideshow/98-old-message-bottle-sets-world-record-005350603.html |publisher=Yahoo News |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160730203016/https://www.yahoo.com/news/blogs/sideshow/98-old-message-bottle-sets-world-record-005350603.html |archivedate=July 30, 2016 |date=August 30, 2012 |deadurl=no }} The 2012 find occurred east of [[Shetland]] by the ''Copious,'' the same fishing vessel involved in the 2006 find.{{cite web |title=World record as message in bottle found after 98 years near Shetland |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-north-east-orkney-shetland-19422354 |publisher=BBC |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151229064308/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-north-east-orkney-shetland-19422354 |archivedate=December 29, 2015 |date=August 30, 2012 |deadurl=no }} * In a 2013 promotional campaign, Norwegian soft drink company [[Solo (Norwegian soft drink)|Solo]] released a 26-foot, 2.7-ton [[wiktionary:replica|replica]] soda bottle outfitted with a customized camera, navigation lights, an [[automatic identification system]], a radar reflector, and GPS tracking technology, all powered by solar panels.{{cite web |last1=Fincher |first1=Jonathan |title=Norwegian soda company sets world's largest message in a bottle adrift |url=http://www.gizmag.com/worlds-largest-message-in-a-bottle/27137/ |publisher=Gizmag|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140827100654/http://www.gizmag.com/worlds-largest-message-in-a-bottle/27137/ |archivedate=August 27, 2014 |date=April 18, 2013 |deadurl=no }} The craft drifted from [[Tenerife]], [[Canary Islands]], while broadcasting its location, but its electronics were stolen by pirates before its five-month trip terminated at [[Los Roques archipelago]] near Venezuela.{{cite web |title=Pirates empty big yellow bottle |url=http://www.canarianweekly.com/pirates-empty-big-yellow-bottle/ |publisher=''Canarian Weekly'' (Canary Islands) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160730024207/http://www.canarianweekly.com/pirates-empty-big-yellow-bottle/ |archivedate=July 30, 2016 |date=September 6, 2013 |deadurl=no }} * In April 2013, a kite-surfer near the mouth of Croatia's [[Neretva]] River recovered a bottle containing a message purporting to have been sent in 1985 from [[Nova Scotia]] to fulfill a promise by a "Jonathan" to write to one "Mary".{{cite web |title=Message in a bottle washes up after 28 years |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-04-18/message-in-a-bottle-washes-up-after-28-years/4636320 |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC Online); Reuters |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140409072810/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-04-18/message-in-a-bottle-washes-up-after-28-years/4636320 |archivedate=April 9, 2014 |date=April 18, 2013 |deadurl=no }} The message received international media attention.{{cite web|last1=Šunjić |first1=Ante |title=Matea pronašla bocu s porukom o kojoj pišu svi svjetski mediji (Matea found a bottle with a message world media would write about) |url=http://dubrovacki.hr/clanak/50789/matea-medak-rezic-cistila-plazu-i-dozivjela-iznenadenje |publisher=''Dubrovack Vjesnik'' (Croatia) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420031001/http://dubrovacki.hr/clanak/50789/matea-medak-rezic-cistila-plazu-i-dozivjela-iznenadenje |archivedate=April 20, 2013 |date=April 17, 2013 |deadurl=yes |language=Croatian |df= }} * In March 2014, a fisherman on the [[Baltic Sea]] near [[Kiel]] recovered a drift bottle containing a Danish postcard dated May 17, 1913 and signed by a then-20-year-old baker's son named Richard Platz, who asked for it to be delivered to his [[Berlin]] address. Researchers located Platz's granddaughter, by then 62, and delivered the 101-year-old message to her, Platz himself having died in 1946.{{cite news |title='World's oldest' message in a bottle arrives home |url=http://www.thelocal.de/20140408/granddaughter-gets-100-year-old-message-in-bottle-reaches-granddaughter |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150114032756/http://www.thelocal.de/20140408/granddaughter-gets-100-year-old-message-in-bottle-reaches-granddaughter |archivedate=January 14, 2015 |newspaper=''The Local'' (Germany) |date=8 April 2014 |deadurl=no }} [[File:18860612 Paula message in bottle.jpg | thumb | right | This bottled message, released June 12, 1886 from a German sailing vessel in the Indian Ocean as part of a drift bottle study, was found on a beach in Western Australia in 2018.]] * An April 2015 find on the North Sea island of [[Amrum]], Germany, of a 108-year-old bottle sent by the [[Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom]] in Plymouth, was one of 1,020 released into the North Sea between 1904 and 1906 by former association president [[George Parker Bidder III]].{{cite web |last1=Huggler |first1=Justin |title=World's oldest message in a bottle washes up in Germany after 108 years at sea |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/germany/11815044/Worlds-oldest-message-in-a-bottle-washes-up-in-Germany-after-108-years-at-sea.html |publisher=''The Telegraph'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160130091409/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/germany/11815044/Worlds-oldest-message-in-a-bottle-washes-up-in-Germany-after-108-years-at-sea.html |archivedate=January 30, 2016 |date=August 20, 2015 |deadurl=no}} * In 2016, Cuban migrants who had fled Cuba in a homemade boat, launched a bottled [[SOS]] message complaining of their treatment while being detained for 42 days aboard a [[United States Coast Guard Cutter]].{{cite web |last1=Oppmann |first1=Patrick |title=Cubans who climbed lighthouse allege inhumane treatment in U.S. custody |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/21/americas/cuba-lighthouse-migrants/ |publisher=CNN |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160722125921/http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/21/americas/cuba-lighthouse-migrants/ |archivedate=July 22, 2016 |date=July 21, 2016 |deadurl=no }} *In late 2016, a [[barnacle]]-encrusted, [[kelp]]-tangled [[GoPro]] video camera was recovered, the camera's [[memory card]] preserving footage showing the prelude to the camera's being swept overboard four years earlier, and also recording its first two hours underwater off [[Fingal Bay, New South Wales|Fingal Bay, NSW]], Australia.{{cite web |last1=Connell |first1=Tim |title=GoPro lost at sea is reunited with its owner after four years |url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/gopro-lost-at-sea-is-reunited-with-its-owner-after-four-years-20161103-gsh2c6.html |publisher=''Sydney Morning Herald'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161112052703/http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/gopro-lost-at-sea-is-reunited-with-its-owner-after-four-years-20161103-gsh2c6.html |archivedate=November 12, 2016 |date=November 3, 2016 |deadurl=no}} *In 2017, a small unmanned boat made by high school students and having solar panels, sensors and camera, drifted on an unexpected path from near [[Maine]], to approach Spain and Portugal, then drift westward back into the Atlantic and northward to be discovered in [[Benbecula]] in the western isles of Scotland. The boat had a waterproof pod containing a chip that collected sensor data.{{cite web |last1=Graham |first1=Gillian |title=Little boat built by students in Kennebunk completes Atlantic crossing |url=http://www.pressherald.com/2017/06/27/kennebunk-student-made-boat-completes-long-overseas-journey/ |publisher=''Portland Press Herald'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170627093653/http://www.pressherald.com/2017/06/27/kennebunk-student-made-boat-completes-long-overseas-journey/ |archivedate=June 27, 2017 |date=June 27, 2017 |deadurl=no}} *In July 2017, a Scottish [[widow]]er seeking female companionship set 2,000 bottled messages adrift at various locations around the U.K., and though claiming he received responses from 50 women, ceased the practice in response to public complaints and an investigation by the [[Scottish Environment Protection Agency]].{{cite web |title=Bottle man lands 50 potential dates |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-south-scotland-40738484 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171113022838/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-south-scotland-40738484 |archivedate=November 13, 2017 |date=July 27, 2017 |deadurl=no }} *In January 2018, a couple walking on a beach in Western Australia discovered a bottled message that had been launched on June 12, 1886 from the German ship ''Paula'' conducting drift bottle experiments for the German Naval Observatory. The message's authenticity was corroborated through the ship captain's original Meteorological Journal, and, at 131 years' duration, eclipsed the previous corroborated record duration of 108 years.{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-43299283 |title=Oldest message in a bottle found on beach |date=March 6, 2018 |publisher=BBC News |language=en-GB |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180307062450/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-43299283 |archivedate=March 7, 2018 |deadurl=no }}{{Cite news |url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/131-year-old-message-bottle-found-australian-beach-180968381/ |title=131-Year-Old Message in a Bottle Found on Australian Beach |date=March 7, 2018 |last=Katz |first=Brigit |publisher=''Smithsonian'' |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6xkqM3nwb?url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/131-year-old-message-bottle-found-australian-beach-180968381/ |archivedate=March 8, 2018 |deadurl=no }} The bottle's thick glass and its opening's 7mm bore are thought to have protected the paper from the elements. *In the summer of 2018, a bottled typewritten message dated March 26, 1930 was discovered in the roof of the twelfth-century [[Goslar Cathedral]] in [[Goslar|Goslar, Germany]], signed by four roofers who bemoaned the economic state of that country. The bottle was discovered by a roofer who was the grandson of one of the signatories, who had been an 18-year-old roofing apprentice in 1930. Goslar's mayor replaced the bottle with a copy of the 1930 message, adding his own confidential message.{{cite news |last1=Beck |first1=Luisa |title=A German roofer working on a cathedral found a message in bottle, written by his grandfather |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/a-german-roofer-working-on-a-cathedral-found-a-message-in-a-bottle-written-by-his-grandfather/2018/09/19/01ddcf8c-b69c-11e8-a2c5-3187f427e253_story.html |work=The Washington Post |date=September 19, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180920113802/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/a-german-roofer-working-on-a-cathedral-found-a-message-in-a-bottle-written-by-his-grandfather/2018/09/19/01ddcf8c-b69c-11e8-a2c5-3187f427e253_story.html |archivedate=September 20, 2018 |deadurl=no }} ("Difficult times of war lie behind us. ... We hope for better times soon to come.") === Long-duration events === {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center" |+ Long-duration (>25-year) events involving messages in bottles.
